title: Don McCullin webchat â your questions answered on war zones, the Beatles and bloody tissues | Art and design | The Guardian
summary: 'photography is about the chemistry of your own emotion . you release the button on this hopefully everlasting image of people who are in unfortunate situations '
'when i came back from wars and revolution , i threw my cameras in a cupboard . i thought it was unnecessary to start persecuting my own family with the camera '
'newspapers promote this narcissistic imagery of celebrities and the rich because it sells newspapers . i do n't that information , i call it a waste of great space '
'i must be involved in the explosive moment , the moment of truth . the moment of decision '
'i went back to vietnam , to saigon , with my son : the first thing i noticed was the lack of noise . the sterility , it was n't the saigon i knew . something had been lost for me '
'a friend , eddie adams , took a of a police chief shooting a suspected vietcon in the head in 1968 . we assumed it would be the end of the vietnam war , but it dragged on for another seven years '

documents.title: that 's all for today
text: don : this whole thing has not been about photography .
it 's been about emotions .
thank you for the questions .
cardinhamtim says : thank you for the inspiration your have given me .
what became of the guvnors of the seven sisters road ( below ) and without photography would your life have followed a similar path ?
the guvnors in their sunday suits , finsbury park , london , 1958 .
mccullin guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 2:22pm well i had to choices when i grew up in finsbury park .
either i ran with the pack , which i 've photographed in the observer , or i tried to stay on the straight and narrow and eventually escape what was a really violent ghetto at the time .
it was by the fortune of this one sunny day that i took my camera and photographed the boys in this derelict building at the end of my street .
i took this photo to the observer newspaper , the editor asked : did you take this ?
i said : yes .
and they published it .
and gave me â£ 50 and it was a king 's ransom , the turning point of my whole life .
it offered me a life away from the bigotry and ignorance and violence of finsbury park .
and since then i 've managed to publish 30 books , numerous exhibitions .
but the final footnote is that i failed my photography test to becomes a raf photographer .
i taught myself everything about photography and darkroom work .
it was all based on the foundations of a terrible beginning in my life .
i 've managed to turn it all around and be where i am .

victoria anderson asks : being a photographer who has experienced multiple scenarios out of your control and potentially fatal how do you deal with what you have seen and the effects on your mental health ?
i 'm just curious to know how you deal with the mental side of the photography you do ?
guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 2:16pm what i do is i thin down the hard part by putting all my energy into the trying part of processing the film , making beautiful prints .

i do n't disassociate , i always retain the memory of what i 've seen because the memory becomes my white stick , it guides me into the next stage , into the darkroom and releasing my emotions into the print .
it might be darker , more sinister .
a lot of fear went into my work , i saw dead children , men with their jaws blown away , holes in their throat .
this had to be got rid of or i would have post-traumatic stress .
which i do n't .
but i do have bad dreams .
i took my soul and my stress into the darkroom .
i belong to this system i 've developed .
it has been a marriage for me , one of the longest lasting of my life .
ongley says : how much of yourself do you feel is ever appropriate or required to give away in order to get close enough to a subject ?
and thank you for your outstanding work .
guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 2:13pm 100 % really .
once i make up my mind , i think of little else .
and once i make the statement that i commit myself to such a subject there is no turning back .
stanley park asks : regarding the beatles ' 1968 photoshoot , how structured was the day , was it totally spontaneous in terms of location choice ?
were any locations vetoed ?
any chance of you retracing your steps for the 50th anniversary of the shoot with mccartney ?
guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 2:12pm one day i received a phone call from the apple company , who were tired of requests from endless photographers to do more shoots of the beatles .
they said to me if we offered you â£ 200 would you consider spending a day with the beatles .
i would have given them â£ 200 .
however , i agree to it .

and we chose the location of the east end of london and i spent a very interesting day which ended up in paul mccartney 's house in st john 's wood having tea at the end of his garden in what looked like a golf ball but was his summerhouse .
i loved being with them but photographically looking back i found this possibly the most unrewarding thing in my photo collection because other people did a much better job .
luke dray says : have you any advice for young photojournalists starting out in the industry ?
guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 2:09pm yes do n't do it .
my concerns are that we are seeing less and less photojournalism and i would think twice before investing your life in thinking this would eventually find you some reward .
my main comments relate to possibly the vanishing future of newspapers .
henleyregatta says : if you could guarantee your safety would you go to syria to document life there under is ?
guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 2:07pm yes i would actually .
it would have be one of the most difficult situation of my life .
there is an english captive there , john cantlie , and we are in contact .
but i do n't think my wife would allow it .
she was angry when i was in damascus last week .
i went to photograph palmyra because i did a book called southern frontiers and palmyra featured big in it in the book and particularly the temple which isis blew up .
i wanted to show the tragedy of the devastation .
i found a hole in a wall and managed to shoot one frame before a russian solider appear out of nowhere and told me to get going .
so you could say my trip was a semi-failure but i wound up in aleppo and homs .
msmariagoldstein asks : your new exhibition is at photo london , probably the largest gathering of photography britain has ever seen .
why do you think there has been this groundswell of interest in photography in britain ?
will london ever overtake paris as the world capital of photography ?
guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 2:02pm well it 's not you see .
new york is the world capital , france next and england third .
there 's more visual , better designed magazines and media outlets .
unfortunately we have far too much emphasis on fashion , accessories , advertising , and now we have the iphone .
this is all part of it .
the value of photography has gone up enormously too .
photographic prints have changed hands for hundreds and thousands of dollars in the market .
unfortunately , i fear the contamination of the art world and photography will steal integrity and commitment from some photographers .

documents.title: 'photography is about the chemistry of your own emotion . you release the button on this hopefully everlasting image of people who are in unfortunate situations '
text: baldricksbrother says : robert capa , one of magnum 's founders , said if your are n't good enough , you 're not close enough .
do you think you got too close ?
it would be trite to say that during your lifetime the world has changed but it has , arguably becoming a more dangerous and murderous place .
photography has played its part ; for the good or the bad ?
guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 1:59pm did i get too close ?
the answer is yes , and i 'm glad i did .
i always use the wide angle lens so it was necessary for me to get even closer .
my main purpose in saying this i wanted to bring you , the viewer , as close as i was standing so that you could almost smell the despair and the pain and the suffering i was witnessing .
photography is n't about cameras , film , chemistry .
it 's the chemistry of your own emotion .
you release the button on this hopefully everlasting image of people who are in such unfortunate situations .

i have a moral feeling that however close i 've been to my subject and however it 's played out by the viewer in their minds , i sincerely believe that all their imagery we 've seen in the last 30 , 40 years , has n't really brought about an understanding that we could see the end of further wars .
the conflicts now have become far worse than they were when i first started out .
nothing could be more des than the imagery of isis beheading prisoners in the desert .
just when you think you 've seen the worse , another load of worse comes along .

documents.title: 'when i came back from wars and revolution , i threw my cameras in a cupboard . i thought it was unnecessary to start persecuting my own family with the camera '
text: stuckinazoo says : when it comes to home and family life , have you always adopted the photographer role and documented the lives of your loved ones ?
or were you opposed to this approach , instead leaving the camera in the hands of others ?
or a happy compromise ?

guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 1:53pm my problem was that when i came back from these areas of conflict , when i came back to england , i would naturally find our own family in the security of our simple home with a caring and loving mother who would have assumed the role of father in my absence .
it was very hard to up the thread of what my responsibility was .
i though it was unnecessary to start persecuting my own family with the camera .
and i have to say that when i came back from wars , and revolution , i put my cameras in a bag and threw them into the cupboard turned my back on them .
there is very little documentation of the families i had in my life .
very little .
almost non existent .
some people 's idea might be considered to be harmful .
it was purely based on my exhaustion , my mental and physical exhaustion .
having seen terrible things .
but i was a good father .
i loved my children .
and still do .

documents.title: 'newspapers promote this narcissistic imagery of celebrities and the rich because it sells newspapers . i do n't that information , i call it a waste of great space '
text: christopher nunn asks : the banality of life today is summed up for me by the navel-gazing selfie on the one hand , and the coverage given to shoals of celebrities on the other .
what happened to looking at our world as it really is , too shameful to recognise ?
guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 1:47pm this is a very good question .
thank you .

my concerns are that celebrities - the wealthy and the celebrities have taken over from the most important images we need to be aware of - the suffering , the side of humanity that is n't in the privileged position in the first place and it 's normally these unfortunate people during wars , revolutions and famines that are the last to be told of the dangers that are coming toward them .

i know that newspapers are under threat of survival and i ca n't help feeling in some quarters that they are encouraged to promote this narcissistic imagery of celebrities and rich footballers and rich financiers because it sells newspapers .
and sadly i do n't call this information , it call it a waste of great space .
i also feel that we are denying ourselves the chance to be educated on the tragedies and the political horrors that are going on out there and that we should be contributing to try and stop .

documents.title: 'i must be involved in the explosive moment , the moment of truth . the moment of decision '
text: nigel roberson says : is photography art ?
this question is constantly being examined , especially in the area of conceptual art , where it 's the idea , not the object .
what is your view ?
guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 1:43pm i 'm always baffled by the conceptual art thing .
an area of photography that has well and truly strayed form where it 's expected to be .
it gives the creative person all sorts of opportunities i could n't bestow upon myself .
i have to expose the film at the moment of crisis , time and history .
i have to photograph the moment .
whereas conceptual photography , you can take your time .
it 's not my cup of tea .
but i do n't see why people should n't experiment anyway they wish > everyone has the democratic right .
i must be involved in the explosive moment , the moment of truth .
the moment of decision .
i 'm a critical person .
that does n't mean i do n't indulge in photographic piece as with my landscapes and still life , the most difficult thing in the world is to photograph and find peace .
john lennon said give peace a chance .
well he was quite right but it 's not going to happen in my lifetime

documents.title: 'i went back to vietnam , to saigon , with my son : the first thing i noticed was the lack of noise . the sterility , it was n't the saigon i knew . something had been lost for me '
text: hamreid66 asks : you are very well travelled and have been in many countries in times of awful wars .
have you ever revisited these countries in times of peace ?
what has been a favourite destination of yours in a non conflict situation ?
guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 1:37pm naturally the most obvious answer to this question is that i went back to vietnam and i took one of my sons , who was in his teens .
it was extraordinary to arrive in saigon and not see thousands of soldiers , military aircraft taking off from the airport .
bear in mind that i was actually deported two days before the war ended because of a story i was involved with in 1972 .
the south vietnamese government had me on a blacklist .
here i was arriving back all these years later with my son .
the first thing i noticed was the lack of noise : all those hercules aeroplanes ; c130s ; the sound of gunfire , none of this was going on .
i found a very peaceful saigon .
but apart from the joyful aspect of arriving in a country that had found peace .
there was another identity .
one of sanitisation .
i feel saigon has been sanitised of this character .
you could be out any time of the day or night buy mountains of black market goods from the americans : socks , shoes , boots , tins of food , you name it , it was for sale .
people uses to do their cooking on the sidewalk .
life was abundant on the street .
now you had this emptiness .
this sterility , it was n't the saigon i knew .
it went back to being graham greene from the quiet american period when the french were there .
but something enormous had been lost for me .

documents.title: 'i walked into a school in biafra and discovered 700 dying children . dying in front of me . which haunts me to this day '
text: idowu omoyele says : what impact , psychological or otherwise , did your coverage of the extraordinary carnage and callousness of the civil war which raged between nigeria and biafra in 1967-70 subsequently have on your life and work ?
do you have any views about the ethics and/or politics of that war ?

how can photography or photojournalism best capture or interpret war or genocide in a way that does not trivialise the suffering ; in a manner , in other words , that honours the noble responsibility of witness and witnessing ?

guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 1:30pm the biafran war was probably the beginning of my awakening in terms of psychology and conscience , due to the fact that one day i walked into a school in biafra and discovered 700 dying children some of whom were collapsing in front of me .
dying in front of me .
and there was one particular boy who was an albino and the photograph i took of him is possibly the most worrying and dreadful image i 've ever taken in my life .
which haunts me to this day .
it was taken in 1969 and it could have been yesterday .

it was a form of genocide , but with hindsight i can look back now and realise the birth of the biafran nation was brought about by the opportunists that though they could break away from the federal government without thinking they could bring about such devastation and the loss of a million lives .
my biggest battle even looking back is to say to myself : you went in for photography but you had no idea of the enormous responsibility that went with covering a conflict of this kind of nature .
philipphilip99 asks : is there a particular shot that you could kick yourself for missing or deciding not to take ?

guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 1:27pm i was on a delegation with times newspaper in peking the proprietor had a personal invitation to meet zhou enlai , the distinguished chinese foreign secretary .
and i 'd cut my face before i left the hotel , shaving .
i was staying in a hotel that was once the house of general chiang kai shek , a nationalistic chinese leader during the second world war .
but in anticipation of this great day , i had misjudged the razor blades .
i went there with blood streaming down my face and during the ultimate moment , i was reaching for some tissued in my bag and missed the grand handshake i 'm managed to keep that secret till today .
so you see i 'm not the great professional people probably think i am !

documents.title: 'a friend , eddie adams , took a of a police chief shooting a suspected vietcon in the head in 1968 . we assumed it would be the end of the vietnam war , but it dragged on for another seven years '
text: gemolo asks : what 's the most powerful image you 've ever seen ?

click here to see the guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 1:22pm it was a taken by a friend of mine , who 's since deceased , a man called eddie adams , of the police chief of saigon shooting the suspected vietcon in the head during the offensive of 1968 .
what made it was the ultimate atrocity committed by a man in a great position of trust taking it upon himself to judge a person who was only a suspect .
executing him as if he has been judged already .
everyone in my business , journalism and the media , assumed it would be the beginning of the end of the vietnam war but in fact the war dragged on for another seven years .
as powerful as this image was .

documents.title: 'i want you to look at my work and not dismiss it as yet another atrocity image '
text: marko burns says : i wondered whether you ever felt there was not something fundamentally troubling about the photographic aesthetics of a well composed war photograph ' , which so many of your photographs are- in the sense of what it might say about the mind of the photographer and what they are trying to communicate .

it strikes me that , for example , the beautifully composed photo of a man with his skull crushed in and a bicycle , could be seen as being photographed or chosen in editing , for its compositional aesthethic qualities , rather than the story ' as such .
should death be well composed ?
how do you balance seeking out beauty ' and facts .
guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 1:19pm this is very good question .

there is a decision that whilst you 're in these areas of conflict and you 're there purely to record the often tragic events , you still persuade yourself to believe there is more time to compose your thereby bringing about a decision : are you dabbling in art , or are you there as purely a news gatherer .
of course , this is a situation i 'm always aware of .
but by the same token i want you to look at my work and not dismiss it out of hand as yet another atrocity image .

it goes without saying , possibly one of the most well known images i 've taken is of an iconic staring soldier , suffering from shell shock and i can be well accused in trading this in the art sense .
should death be well composed ?
there is no need to compose death .
it 's the final statement .
death .
id4233501 asks : i realise you have experienced many profound events but had photography been invented earlier , what events/people would you like to have photographed from history and why ?
guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 1:16pm most certainly the boxer revolution ; the storming of the peking palace ; the battle of omdurman in the sudan , and churchill .
all under the office of lord kitchener .
i would have loved to be in the laurence of arabia scene too .

documents.title: 'i have never had a fitness programme in my life . but i 've tried to be physically strong '
text: jonnoh asks : can you offer insights on how you managed to keep your cool in difficult situations or did it have any impact on your psychological health afterwards ?
did you have a fitness programme ?
thank you guardian contributor donmccullin 17 may 2016 1:14pm i 've never had a fitness programme in my life .
i 've always tried to be physically strong .
because photography is n't about pressing the button .
its about visual awareness .
but that has to be backed up by physical strength .
i look healthy but i am not
don mccullin is here now : hello .
here i am , i am very pleased to be here and frankly speaking , i 'm not incapable of answering any question .
anything you choose to throw at me , i 'm very happy to try and answer .
thank you , don don mccullin .
furlong/getty images

documents.title: post your questions for don mccullin
text: from the streets of swinging london to the killing fields of vietnam , photographer don mccullin has consistently captured the madness of the modern age .
now 80 , he 's best known for his images of war , but his bucolic landscapes and photos of poverty in the northern england are equally powerful .

another famous series was of the beatles goofing around during the recording of the white album , though mccullin holds no truck with celebrity , telling the observer : fake tans , beckhams , jamie oliver .
i ca n't take any more of it .
that 's why i 'm going to syria .
he duly went to war-torn aleppo , and just this month has been photographing the recently recaptured palmyra .
he 's been named master of photography at this year 's photo london festival , and with an accompanying retrospective opening this week , mccullin joins us to answer your questions .
the live webchat will take place 1pm bst on tuesday 17 may post your questions in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The legendary photographer answered your questions on the chemistry of taking why he didn't snap his family and why too close is not close enough.
¢ Don McCullin: photography isn't looking, it's feeling' in.
